title: 110_s2006
content: The "Rate Payer Recovery Act of 2007" may be cited as the short title. It includes disaster assistance for power transmission and distribution facilities. The "Rate Payer Recovery Act of 2007" provides disaster assistance for private or investor-owned power facilities, including transmission and distribution facilities that serve retail customers under State or local jurisdiction. This includes leased facilities. Contributions are subject to certain conditions outlined in the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act. The "Rate Payer Recovery Act of 2007" provides disaster assistance for private or investor-owned power facilities damaged by a major disaster. Assistance includes repair, restoration, reconstruction, or replacement of the facility and associated expenses. Conditions for assistance include defining a "previous major disaster" as one occurring within 10 years before the current disaster declaration. The President may provide contributions to private or investor-owned power facilities if the cost of repairing or replacing them after a previous major disaster exceeded certain thresholds. Private or investor-owned power facilities may apply for Federal assistance if 25 percent or more of the population in the area had taxable income below the Federal poverty level in the year before the previous major disaster. Owners must apply within 30 days of a disaster declaration or after contributing $10,000,000 towards repair costs. Private or investor-owned power facilities affected by a major disaster can request Federal assistance for repair, restoration, or replacement. The assistance is limited to costs exceeding $10,000,000 directly incurred by the owner. The President must approve or disapprove applications within 30 days. Private or investor-owned power facilities affected by a major disaster can request Federal assistance for repair, restoration, or replacement. The Federal share for these facilities is amended to include private or investor-owned power facilities. In cases where the facility owner determines it's not in the public welfare to repair, they can opt for a contribution equal to 75% of the Federal estimate. The Federal share for repairing private or investor-owned power facilities affected by a major disaster is amended to include management expenses. Funds can be used for repairing, expanding, or constructing power facilities, as well as for hazard mitigation measures. Eligible costs are defined in the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act. The Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act is amended to include private or investor-owned power facilities for repair and management expenses in case of a major disaster. Eligible costs cover repairing, expanding, or constructing power facilities and implementing hazard mitigation measures. The Secretary of Homeland Security must create regulations within 180 days of the Act's enactment to implement the Act and its amendments. The Act and its amendments will take effect 60 days after enactment, with Section 3 taking effect immediately.
